title: Banks card margins decline as customers switch
text:
Banks say rule changes introduced in 2011 are encouraging a lot more people to choose low rate credit cards Photo: AFR
Major banks admit the margins they earn on credit cards jumped by around 2 per cent after the financial crisis hit, but despite sharp declines in their funding costs, profitability has been flat or declining since then as more people switch to low rate cards.
ANZ, Westpac and Commonwealth banks said funding makes up less than a quarter of the total cost of cards and "effective interest rates" on cards has been falling due to more people paying off cards before interest kicks in and more generous promotions like 0 per cent on balance transfers up to two years.
The banks will not disclose their actual margins, but point out other costs that further reduce this.
They include relatively high losses due to high fraud rates on cards and the fact that they are unsecured loans, higher capital held against credit card debt, the cost of issuing cards, including rewards programs and interest-free periods, and processing millions of transactions a day. In recent years there has also been extra spending needed due to technological change.
Advertisement "There has been a high level of innovation in the credit cards market including the introduction of contactless payments, mobile payments, chip and PIN authorisation, anti-fraud measures and digitisation of services," Westpac said. The New Payments Platform, which will be in place by 2017, is costing banks about $1 billion.
However, around $2 billion paid annually in interchange fees to banks by merchants pays for the cost of issuing cards, rewards programs, interest-free periods and the cost of fraud.
Westpac said the decline in so called "revolve" rates – the percentage of card holders who pay interest – from 73.7 per cent to 64.1 per cent since January 2013 has had a "far bigger impact on margins than the official cash rate reductions", which were 0.75 per cent in the same period.
Estimates by the Reserve Bank put the average "spread" banks make on cards above their cost of funds at around 9 per cent for all cards at average "effective rates" of 11.6 per cent for the March quarter. This is up from about 6 per cent in 2007. The spread is 14.75 per cent where interest is paid, which is now at effective rates of 17 per cent.
Since 2011, it said effective rates had declined by between 1 and 2 per cent since the cash rate had declined by 2.75 per cent to 2 per cent
ANZ bank said higher spreads above funding on effective interest rates are justified because there is more risk in the economy than prior to the financial crisis.
"A fall in interest rates, by definition, is symptomatic of an economy that is or is likely to be performing below capacity," it said in its submission to a Senate credit card inquiry. "The change in spread in recent years is consistent with these trends."
All banks say credit card competition is high and both ANZ and Westpac said credit cards are "the most switched" of their banking products.
Westpac said a lot more of its customers are also now taking up low-rate cards, in part due to tougher rules introduced in 2011 which has forced banks to tell consumers the full cost of their cards and the need for them to opt in to receiving unsolicited card offers.
"Over 30 per cent of total customer credit card balances across the Westpac Group are held in low-rate accounts," it said. "This has increased from 23 per cent in 2010. In the last two years, low-rate cards have accounted for over 50 per cent of all new sales."
Mutual lender Bank Australia (formerly Bank Mecu) and the Customer Owner Banking Association say all their cards are low-rate, ranging between 8 and 12 per cent. But cuts to interchange fees they receive from merchants being considered by the RBA may mean they have to raise their rates, reducing the number of lower-rate options for consumers.
"If you do reduce the average interchange fee that will reduce the capacity to issue low-rate cards," COBA's head of public affairs, Luke Lawler ,told the inquiry in Melbourne on Thursday.
"[But] the RBA has identified a problem – on certain cards there is very high rates. We are quite open to capping the very high [interchange fee] cards."
